Scouting program idea-an arbitrary number of Scout NFTs, to which tokens are periodically air dropped. Tokens can either be traded or burned to recommend a project to the governors of the fund. If they are traded, the scout gets fewer tokens next time, if they are burned, the scout gets more.

A rolling fund that participates in tradfi deals has to meet much stricter obligations than a non rolling fund. Not only that, but the idea of when to price in/out of a rolling fund becomes more difficult as it implies an ability to calculate fund value at any time, which wouldn’t be possible if we’re targeting less liquid, early stage deals. If this entity will make any TradFi deals (implied securities holdings) then having it be unregulated, without accreditation is not possible (unless we all want to absorb legal liability). Best way is to either form a legal entity (which will have a trade off for who can join) or avoid doing TradFi deals using the DAO.

I have been brainstorming how to better align incentives in an investing DAO (I am actually working on a platform that offers investing DAOs as a service - https://coinocracy.finance) and as an investing DAO you want to optimize for 2 things - good deal flow, and being value add for your portfolio. Instead of traditional carry going to managers, in a DAO it can be structured in the smart contracts to go to those that are value add (either by being lead or voted on by portfolio cos)

I work at https://syndicate.io — happy to intro — and we help create investment club DAOs to allow non-accredited investors to participate in these sorts of TradFi deals. One of the ideas I've been floating myself lately is that a community (e.g. Hyperscale) can have many investment clubs (squads of capital with high social cohesion) that can participate in the community seed rounds of incubated projects.

Do we want to be able to invest in pre-token rounds? Buying equity with token warrants?

This is good, but as already mentioned I think this list is too traditional. We have most of these for my web3 projects but not all. Honestly things are moving so fast roadmap, competitor overview, and research changes frequently. I'd put more weight around at least MVP (not simply idea), problem/solution, team history, tokenomics, and is there a plan for governance.
Not sure how deep you can go in one week from time of application to approval.
Depth also comes with ownership and decision power
if we expect the end-decision to be made by a large group of people then you can't go for depth
however, if the group entrusts a small group of people to make a call, then you can have more depth
even in a week
but depth requires effort in terms of research and outreach so should be rewarded to the people digesting the learning for the collective

I sit on the council of a DAO which has 12 seats and the process is suggestion from community (here application), one council member moves worthy suggestion to active proposals for voting, council has one week to vote, 8/12 is considered passed and moves to community veto period. This also has open ended time for review prior to moving to proposal. So, that is much more time than 1 week, but here we can automate things and shorten the timeframe.
Very interesting
but isn't it strange to have the community vote after the council?
Ideally you want to use the crowd to increase the signal/noise ratio

Agreed and apologies for the too traditional list (my background is partly in VC haha). Maybe I could ask then, which commonalities are present in web3 companies today which have proven to be impactful? And how can the fund as a structure of the DAO strategically help grow these companies?
Which failures have they faced, which failures/risks are we willing to face?

I would think that applications go through a programmatic reviewing system where community members learn by reviewing and get paid a tiny bit. and from that we look at the ones that come out positively with an expert counsil
Maybe asking these questions can help sharpen the investment focus and outlook

I actually think that it will be fairly straightforward to figure out what we want to ask from applying projects. The harder question here is how to organize and callibrate our own efforts to review them

Specific to web3 is also important to evaluate the technology, on top of what tech are they building and some experts on this. Also haven’t seen this mentioned much but is there a degree of impact / mission driven assessed? If it moves the needle forward for more opportunities, changing destructive industries, health, climate, finance, etc??

What I would propose is to have an binary voting system where we have people review up to 5 sets of companies per iteration. If we ensure that we have 5 data points on each company, we can only look with expert councils to the top X percent of deals reviewed by the community.

Binary voting is easy because you dont have to give more context nor is it complex to process. People just have to answer the question, reading through these 2 companies, in which one would you invest A or B

Also interesting to explore the idea of voting mentioned as yes/no vs one or two people being really inspired by the idea and having the chance to pound the table and root for the team to show others the potential he/she sees on the team that perhaps others had missed and then proceed to voting. (Thinking about many NOs that were huge success)
Obviously we have to make assumptions about what working with a large group of people means
If we want to be a technocracy or representational democracy.
An additional danger is the fact that applicants can join and come shout for themselves
So in my mind we don't want to optimize for community members bouncing the table
Hmm trueee
This is what I would propose to make a first selection before going to council

I think vision and understanding of where web3 is going carries a lot of weight. You will get a percentage that doesn't understand web3, a percentage that is chasing fads, and then what we want is a group that understand the problems web3 solves and how to get there.
So what you're saying then is that there should be quality control to become a reviewer?
Makes sense though, crowdfunding is also a really bad proxy for VC
It should be considered a badge of web3 honor to be a reviewer in our system

Could be good to consider. In my situation we use a little known but robust blockchain which no one here would know and probably be overlooked. But on another project we are using Ethereum which is widely used but has its limitations around fees and the hope of v2.0. Maybe not so much about which blockchain but why
Not necessarily quality control but this should be considered on both sides of the deal. We need a mix. I know web3 but I have never looked at term sheets 😅
We could make the system weighted

Another approach is coordinating the reviews where in an open reddit type forum people people can provide their view on different aspects of the company for others to understand and even make comments that way some evaluate the idea entirely others merely some areas they are proficient in (but this might not be necessarily needed as these companies will be very early)
Where we give more weight to the judgement according to their status and tenure
This will then become a bit like ProductHunt
Where again the founders will take an important part of the conversation
and people wont speak their true mind because of that fact and because it is public
We could ask founder to refrain from joining in the conversation, but in a pseudonomous world that is really hard to enforce
Is this similar to what you meant with weighted?  Just throwing ideas out there for inspiration

I've actually built a scorecard for evaluating investment decisions on a somewhat objective basis - the scorecard was built for web2.0 companies so doesn't include additional bits around tokenomics and the like but could be a good starting point
Super interesting obviously
I would make it a mainly self-referencing system
Where in the ground state of the network everyone has the same weight but if you correctly identify promising deals and do so consistently
then you end higher on the leaderboard
Attached here for reference
sorry for crossposting but how does the DAO accumulate funds?
to invest
Good question, in my mind the DAO should receive both Carried and operating fees
just like a man-co in VC funds
Down the road we could envision the DAO co-investing with the fund it helps deploy
The operating costs should go to correctly incentivise people to help run the investment process and the carried should help grow the treasury
I might be speaking out of turn as this is probably something that Sam and co decided already
I read up on https://hyperscale.notion.site/Vision-2201287712f743a99a044d8a2de6220e which aims at 100B fund. Whos bringing it

messages.content:
Founder here, really excited to see how quickly Hyperscale got off the ground in 5 days 🤯 

**Sharing some thoughts:**
1. The singular reason that attracted me - I don't need to spend time pitching while in exploration phase.
2. The app is simple - I think this will be a bigger game changer than most realize, especially for capturing 2nd time founders. 
3.  $200k for 5% feels low, both for the general market and crypto. This will impact future rounds, and token economics. 
4. As a founder confident in raising, the offer is just not exciting (n of 1). But this could mean two things - We'll end up attracting B-players and overlooked A-players.

**My thesis** - web3 founders need time and $ to explore, there is no "fundraising product" to help them do so. If this fund wants to fund the first(and more) $100B+ web3 company, it has to be a "no brainer" for even the best founders to start by taking a check from HyperScale.
** In other words, founder should be like uh do I talk to my guys at a16 and have 3 meetings and bullshit, or should i just take this starter check from HyperScale and get going. 
**

*(I am a 2nd time founder, YC-backed, early at Instacart, engineer at Amazon)*

Thoughts welcome!

Is it worth having a council selected by the community and swapped every 3-6 months? This way a quick 48 hour voting period could follow applications where the entire community can up or down vote and if a percentage in favor is reached it goes to the council to spend the remaining 5 days to vet further and communicate directly with the Founders?
Doesnt hurt to be ambitious, but that is not what we are doing here right now. Right now the funds come out of Sams pocket
oof, I thought it was something where DAO participants could stake their own capital
get exposure to VC investing without much capital per person
Down the line that becomes an obvious next step
Thats the plan for future 100%
But legally a lot more complex
Yes I understand that
Believe me, I got in the hairs of the SEC a couple weeks back haha
you dont want that
Just not something we are going to build in days.
Securities law in the US is ridiculous
No but with a large enough movement we could influence policy - but not overnight
remembering MetaCartel and LAO
the way they managed it almost
Any idea on what basis the first 10m (that will come out of Sama if I didn´t missread) will be deployed?

Yeah thats the key for a number of folks, we want to get into the market now, as in this week. Then overtime build the most robust and next gen structure, use that to both have fun and get returns, but also use it as an example of how well it can work and use that to influence policymakers.
Exactly
Based on whatever we design here, as long as it doesnt get him into legal trouble.
so lets say there is no DAO token right now. Who gets to vote?
Awesome
TBD, likely something offchain for those building here on discord
This is what we were discussin above
ah cool
But if we get some shit hot ideas on how to do it onchain too I personally would love to see that.
as a Dev, for our defi protocol we did it onchain
We first have to agree on the premises underpinning how we want to review and judge
onchain is best, but will take time
and then we build an off-chain version of that
identified key contributors on discord, whipped up a sample token on rinkeby and used snapshot
to then take that on-chain
all took less than an hour
Ok thats interesting
no cost, vote on chain and didnt represent actual token
Can we see that somewhere?

Yep, I put a note in one of the channels cant remember which at this point saying basically

Voting Processes
Onchain/Offchain Decision
Incentivisationa and Rewards
Tooling
Execute
Should be our prioirtiy flow
check https://brahma.fi discord

messages.content: disclosure: I'm a dev for brahma.fi
haha cool disclosure - good to have experts around the table
Also Ill note our #legacy-voting channel is dead, we need folks to start putting out good and concete ideas in there
We have been discussing voting here above at length
something like this
Yup just dont want it to get lost
https://www.notion.so/Application-Review-Process-60839f53b4da407bb0f9d5fc88d01324
Tried crystallizing some things here
IMO all the numbers, 500 reviewers sound very arbitrary
the numbers are completely arbitrary
lols
just trying to think through the numbers
how do we decide out of 10k people (assuming dao has a lot) who gets to vote
They should obviously be parameters
That is a good question, can everyone become a reviewer?
should everyone be able to become a reviewer?
great question
i think they should
thats the point of DAO
all participants should have the right to contribute to core flow of the DAO
If the process is clearly defined then reviewing shouldn't be exclusionary
Agree on everyone being part of it, still like the idea of rewarding someone with domain expertise for a deeper review level too though.
hmm. you are not wrong
Yes but we cant become stupid
how do you even grade someone
It seems like a multi step process makes sense with clear documentation at each step and tracking on the back end
given a binary choice did they make a right decision
and for instance in regular VC, crowd funding is a bad proxy for good investments
There is no right or wrong, except for the ones we hard code
It is just which one would you back: A or B
nothing more
grading can happen long form by tracking users votes and a combination of the gains such an user has over the votes they submit for example
no points, no grading
*gains on investments
Have them as SME's that the DAO votes on to do detailed reviews on specific domains. Essentially as delegates in a way for certain verticals.
but grading is hard because giving an 8 out of 10 is not the same for someone else
I am using the term grade loosely
Yes this should in my mind be the next step in the process
more like a tracking where we can see how user voted and what the results of those votes would have resulted in over a life time mock portfolio
in case something like this makes sense, I'd be happy to help set it up
doesn't seem like this determination should be an emergent property as opposed to by assigning individuals to verticals
Making voting ubiquitous across the DAO really only works if the voting structure is clearly outlined and totally objective; otherwise the outcome can be totally skewed
yessir

In theory yes but thats a long term process, it would take many iterations for that to come out data driven vs doing it this way we can have people apply to be SMEs and the onus is on them to show domain expertise, term limited role so if they are failing based on data they term out and are not reappointed.
I believe that we should just pass every application though a community voting based system
to then have councils judge the ones with the best scores
In the beginning that could be a generalist council
That makes sense, but it seems that we could have it both ways intitially maybe run an A/B test of the systems
OK yeah that works also, its basically just flipping the filter stage to after voting.
and then we can start having verticalised councils
one with broader voting mechanisms and review processing and one with assigned reviewers
yes
OK I like this.
the community is the filter

It would be cool if there was a voting mechanism in place that essentially scored the opportunities across a more tight knit group within the DAO (potentially a subDAO).  And those scores were then presented to the broader DAO to have final decision
and then the community elected council passes final judgement
So the broader community can make an informed decision but still have final say - for the sake of maintaining the value and sanctity of the DAO
I actually think it would be interesting if it went the other way - final say sits with the entire community
If it is run behind closed doors and anonymity
then maybe yes
This sounds a lot like the democratic process in the US with elected representatives -- and we've all seen how well that has turned out..
but it cant be a popularity contest
lmao
Trusting your elected officials to act in your best interest just doesn't work lol
Thats essentially how delegation works in web3 DAOs tho
Yes you cant expect the investment theses to have depth
if everyone is the judge
Agreed - total anonymity on the scoring process (with potentially a rotating core scoring team).  And scores are presented to the broader community to vote on final decision
Fair
I disagree with that
Yeah there needs to be a filter stage, either first or last, otherwise we just blow through 10m in Sams cash with a low likelyhood of RoI
how come?
whats your thinking?
Doesn't mean we need to follow suit though - no better time to buck the trend if we think there's a better system to implement
It takes a lot of time and energy to really understand a deal
Yes most people dont get how much work it is to do even basic DD, and we are talking about days of timeframe here to do that work
You cant expect the whole DAO to take the time to really understand a whole set of deals

At this stage of investing, investment decision is honestly mostly around the team + roadmap + GTM motion; with team being the core focus -- idt investment decision in these cases is that deep of a dive

I think if we create a standardised information and voting flow we could crowdsource extremely good information and thinking from multiple perspectives, which then can be reviewed by the community at large
before votes happen
We should indeed try to tap into the insights of the community
additionally, this could serve as a great way to filter our good thinkers over time and double up as a proof of work mechanism on this side of the fence
I second this - all comes down to ability to standardize and synthesize for the broader community
True
Currently working on a bare bones idea page here but you guys just move so damn fast lol
Hahah yeah, Sat night and sun morning was crazy. Ideas had been worked on and rejected while I was stil typing them up into notion
We do something similar at my VC fund -- core team scores an opportunity and presents a high level overview to the IC who then also score the deal
Binary voting where people can add a mini investment thesis
If the wtd avg score is above a certain threshold, the deal passes process

Agree with @JayIRL. Some sort of filtering is likely needed. Perhaps an investment committee that brings possible deals to a vote. Art Blocks has a curation board to filter for top projects. The board's keen eye is widely trusted by the community. Key sales driver.

Yes similar to what I mentioned before. More than likely the community voting on one application will not be the same as the next the following week. But, the filtering board should be mostly consistent during a determined period of time.
over time you could even have the board rotation automatic based on voting history. Top x participants move to the board every month, etc

I think transparency should remain a core tenet of the DAO -- if the filtering board scores a deal poorly, I don't think that deal should be removed from presentation to the DAO.  It should remain but with a clear red flag based on the score provided, which will serve as a natural filtering
On no for sure, everthging the SMes or Council or Board group does needs to be 100% transparenet and jusified
Agree. Curated list. You have one for all applications and one for board recommended
That's a good point. The ever-changing member composition of the DAO impacts investment decisions.

If for example we have a HealthTech proposal and I vote it down or vote it through as an SME I need to be writing the why and justification, putting the effort to tell the other DAO members the why I think its good/bad based on my domain expertise etc.
Proposed Selection process
Yes and then this reduces the time it requires the community to research, or not
Agreed.  But in your scenario, can a proposal that you reject still pass through if the broader community votes to do so?  Or will that proposal be null from the voting process?
I think yes

I'm aligned then.  Filtering committee highlights "good vs bad" proposals (for lack of a more sophisticated term) and broader DAO then votes, but still retains the right to go against the initial suggestion provided by the committee
Maybe it sets a higher benchmark. Board approved needs 51% community yes, Board flagged requires 80% community approval

I dont think it should be a kill vote no, This is why I wanted it up front so that folks can vote with the SME reviews having been done and some domain context and text for them to make decisions based on if its not their area of expertise. If we move the SMEs to the end then I think it likely is a killing vote.
I like this.  I think it makes total sense and retains most power possible for the DAO + allows for deeper dives and more educated decision making processes for investments
Yes, would be wise for investment committee to lay out thesis on why they are bringing a vote on x company/how it arrived at y decision. perhaps we need a brief template for that.
And include board voting results: These 7 voted in support these 5 said no and these 3 abstained
Right on

I believe a subjective scoring mechanism is the best approach to arrive at yes vs no across the committee w/ a set threshold.  All scores can then be presented in addition to final votes + investment thesis
filtering / classification is the first thing an AI could help with.  easy to spot-check to tune the model, a light overlay of tags to guide further review
This would make it MUCH easier for community vote. Then a simple notification can go out and quick 24 hour voting period or something of the sort

And not sure if you all saw what Mercury has done with Mercury Raise (https://mercury.com/raise) - but it could be cool to implement something here as well to support future financing needs of these businesses

messages.content: What do folks think about the investment committee soliciting feedback from the community as part of their decision making process? Surely there could be instances were a non-committee member has specialized knowledge that the committee members may not.

Supportive, but I'd be careful not to make the process too clunky.  At the end of the day, idt the process for a sub $1M check should be tooooo exhaustive or technical.  For many of our smaller checks we write, we typically take it at face value at the tech works for example and limit our technical diligence
I am not sure why the investment committee should perform this job, it seems overly restrictive
Just a side note: This can never be called an investment comittee needs to be more generic to stay safe and not be formal investment advisory work
If we have pre-determined investment memo formats and information we agree on as important, anyone should be able to make their case as to why an investment is make sense
filtering board work?
yup
the community can then decide what arguments they llike and vote
maybe include veto power initial if we want to ensure an additional quality check
Yep. Filtering board soliciting feedback from non-members could make the process more clunky. Perhaps constructing the most well rounded board possible is the way to go and hope for the best.

**Information flow** (potential alternative to a board)
Before any review can happen, we need to have accurate information.
1.0) The first step here would constitute a way to filter out whether a project has filled out their application correctly.
1.1) Next, we would likely want to understand if the basic idea of the project is something of interest as an investment.
As mentioned previously in one of the comments, this basic determination would require some basic idea of what constitutes an investment of interest.
A checklist of attributes that has been previously outlined internally could serve as an initial check-point. This checklist would have to be completed by a minimum number of users (?), who attach their profile to the checklist to put their own reputation at stake (?)

2.0) As a next step, the process should escalate to creating an investment memo(s), which argue in favor or against an investment. This Document should also be pre-defined in structure.
Such memos ensure that at least a modicum of due diligence has been performed before a vote happens on whether to invest in a project or not.    
As the community develops the standards here, that should actually take care of what we care about as a group, which can then further refine the thesis of the fund or the other selection processes. 
Additionally, such memos and the subsequent votes can serve as a great way to track the hit rate a user has in terms of their potential lifetime performance of investments they choose.
Yes

I think its great to set criteria for investments of interest to be an initial filter (or even in some cases be an "Auto Invest Category")

**Some thoughts on investments of interest:**
1. Startups that are combating climate change
2. Startups that are revolutionizing transportation.
3. Startups that are developing the "ecosystem of Hyperscale"
4. Startups that are improving on the infrastructure of web3

Feedback? Additions?

**To define "Ecosystem of Hyperscale"**

Any startups that are developing things that will help us scale. For instance, in #website-development @kevalin mentioned we need someone to keep track of "what has been done" and "what are our next priorities". If someone would develop a more efficient tool or automating this process, that would be great. 

Also, this category constitutes things that will help with "What DAOs & community need" (another area of focus mentioned in the announcement today). An example investment could be a startup pitching to help with "Community Onboarding for DAOs."
Last thought here, maybe for the first round, our **primary selection criteria** is "what startup will help us and other web 3 companies to scale most efficiently?" @kevalin  thoughts?

I think, even though perhaps is more broad, that it could be smart not to tie ourselves to specific verticals and take a more principled approach. 

Perhaps something like: startups that are disrupting/changing the dynamics of established industries through web3? For example (full disclosure no way involved with them) KlimaDAO is transforming C02 removal through web3 and unlocking a lot of value. Others can do the same for other verticals. Just my 2 cents.

I like that as well as the **primary selection criteria**. 
If people think that having a primary selection criteria for the first investment will be helpful, we can wait here for other thoughts and then have a vote on them. So far we have
"startups that are disrupting/changing the dynamics of established industries through web3?"
"what startup will build something to help web 3 companies scale most efficiently?"

I think for season 1 it would be beneficial to keep it open ended under the umbrella of web3 to encourage all applications and gather data and for future seasons there can be tracks or paths like the discussion above

can someone explain what this means?  

is the investment deal a token swap?
Said that same thing when I read that

Hyperscale Selection Characteristics:

• deal size is very small
• application process is very easy
• venture stage is very early / germination

Likely to attract a LOT of loose and untested ideas.

Play to strengths…
We want to objectively (as possible) rank the most capable PEOPLE in each season.

At this stage… Projects can change and evolve much more easily than personnel.

The selection is not a pass/fail test to a yes/no decision it is a RANKING of applicants with the highest ranking gaining approval in that season. 

All we then have to do is drive high traffic to achieve high competition.

Trying to pick winning ideas is so subjective and so uncertain at this early stage as to be almost entirely stochastic. At least capable people should be able to provide evidence of their capabilities that can be weighed as objectively as possible.

It’s also extremely difficult to generate standardised data for scoring ideas and ventures.

But scoring people as agents of probable success is something that we could build standardised data for
Can we train AI to predict who might be a successful entrepreneur?
with enough historical data and real-time data yes

Of course, but you recognise my main point? Measuring people and their capabilities will lead to more, and more easily standardised data than trying to collect data on the value of an untested idea. Ideas/ventures/projects are all very different and this makes it very difficult to propose a standardised system of comparison.

I think focusing on the founders is 100% the way to go. Almost to the point of ignoring the value of the initial proposal. 

This also better fits the two way democratised ownership model where we expect projects to cross collaborate and gravitate their efforts to the most valuable project.
With a token that invests capital but also conveys mixed equity in the fund you create a group of a few hundred talented people with 40 or so new ideas and $10m to explore the space
re: investment analysis -- Yes, agree with the sentiment of heavily weighing founders' potential in seed phase. at this stage, most teams don't have a working product, let alone revenue.
how you going to deal with anon founders? It's not something uncommon for web3 projects.
What is the downside for trying to measure for both? I don't think we are going to get to a standardization point in season 1.

Additionally, if you're exclusively evaluating on the pedigrees of founders you're not doing anything discernibly different than what we already see in the world today and what seems to often lead to a lack of distribution in capital when it comes to diversity.
There are plenty of great founders that never went stanford, didn't get into YC and still have the chops to build great projects/companies.
Nothing compels you to select for Stanford! Lol
I just want to invest in founders with potential to change the world. Pedigree or not.
Plenty of ways you can assess capabilities, skills, decision making, etc and you can do it anonymously if that was a requirement
this is the credentials and Mit/Stanford for web3

I imagine you might want to take 1,000 applications and pick out the highest ranking 50, which are at the hockey stick end of the curve. 
Give them all some funds to get going and incentivise collaboration. Let nature do it’s thing.
I think the idea is very important. YC tried the “high potential founders with no ideas” approach before and iirc it didn’t work very well.

I guess the point I'm trying to make is it's not a one size fits all problem and startups/projects need to be evaluated from a variety of viewpoints.  With the proper infrastructure they should be able to be analyzed based on their abilities and what they're building.
It's not the early 2000's anymore, building products is stupid cheap and even gaining your first few customers. Even early data can start to tell a story.
That’s a good point. Here each project would have an idea. Post approval you own 95% of your idea and 0.1% of every other idea. You want your idea to be the one that attracts the collab.
Yes, I think even high potential founders work best if they have a passionate project to coalesce around
Just finding great people and telling them to go find ways to spend money to start a business is asking for trouble imho 😅
Yes, I can imagine how that might go
I think that’s what happens on Wall Street actually …
Eat each other
Anyway, trying to propose a model that fits web3 principles
Which is sort of community, collaboration, democratised ownership

How is the community thinking about the data communication relationship with the startup/project and DAO?
from application to post application tracking (if pass) to due diligence to post investment

Both quality of ideas and founders are important. Though excellent ideas are easier to come by than excellent ppl. personally, i'm more partial to backing high caliber founders with a moderately good idea over a moderately good founder with a high caliber idea because execution is king. in the end, high caliber founders are better pivoters and more likely to figure out high caliber ideas.

Deal sourcing might still be a problem looking  at all the early stage VC. An interesting concept would be to engage developers as „scouts“. Whenever they see an interesting ideas they can promote them for an investments. That way we could get people early, even before they know that they want funding
How would you rate first time founders?
I agree, both are important, I think overtime we can potentially build some infrastructure to better support talented founders without a product / idea, but I don't think we should start there.
Alternatively, we can have an x percentage of the initial season be supporting talented founders with out a product
It all depends on what we attract
But you can assess people more easily and more accurately than you can assess ideas.
Predicting which ideas will pan out is highly subjective. But interview 10 people and you can usually pick out the stronger 1 or 2.
You can test people for decision making, resourcefulness, intelligence, EQ, etc, etc. Not perfectly but with excellent correlation.
If you want to assess 1,000 applications per week from a global point of view, you will need to automate it
By the time you are ready for follow on funding, you will know a lot more.
Let high competition be the filter.

Good write-up by Ben Yoskovitz on how to evaluate first time founders. Agree with his points. not an exhaustive list, but a solid foundation.  https://www.instigatorblog.com/founder-dna-how-investors-evaluate-startup-founders/2010/10/21/

messages.content: What does success look like to someone without an idea / product? How do we support that? I think we can potentially experiment with funding founders without a product, but im not sure that should be the sole criteria
Willing to experiment and then measure outcomes though 🙂
that's a great list, but how do you quantify these things?
I think everyone should be able to articulate a unique (ish) project. I’m saying we should very heavily weight the scoring for founders over the idea.
I’d agree with that.  Ideas tend to pivot, and the truly great ideas tend to sound ridiculous at first anyway

If a season has 45 projects and they each get $200k, I would expect 80% of them to fail within 3-6 months. People should then be able to coalesce around the remaining 20% either via the shared equity of the token or cutting merge deals themselves.
99% of the value is created by 1/<big number> of the projects
Are we talking about only funding idea stage projects?
this is a very high and fast failure rate
People will be applying for $200k to $1m so that should give an idea of what stage projects will be at. Nobody with $5m revenue is gonna apply
not necessarily
Non-seed stage ideas would probably not want to / have a hard time convincing existing investors they’re going to trade 5% for 200k.
depending on the value the community adds you might be surprised
we see series A companies go through YC all the time
I’m open minded about everything at this point

Building anything is hard and always comes with a variety of pitfalls, especially anything meant to be venture scale.  Looking at a company only from the numbers doesn’t always tell the full story, so it’s often a combination of both.

- What issues the team is facing and is there anything we as investors can do to to help them solve? (Intros, partnerships, hiring, etc)  We can’t help if we don’t know they need it.

- If the company is performing well, should we exercise our pro-rata rights or like a16z will tend to do, drop a term sheet before they even start raising? We’re potentially going to get diluted in future rounds, so if we end up with a very small piece of the pie of our biggest winners we still don’t see the outsized returns we were looking for.

- Without data from our portfolio companies, how do measure the health of the portfolio as a whole? How do we do our year end accounting, etc ? 

This is just for our portfolio, but when you start to think about the pipeline we could and should monitor that as well.

- Easily move through diligence
- Compare a company to its peers 
- If we pass, it doesn’t mean they can’t be great, how can we maintain a relationship with them so if things turn around / look good we can still get our foot in the door. Every unicorn investment we pass on because it was too early becomes a huge opportunity cost.
- How can we help companies that have yet to get an investment from us, so they know we actually bring value besides just funding?

- How do we start building a data wharehouse so we can model a neural net to invest or find the best potential  candidates? Find the patterns that were not seeing. 

Our process of monitoring and getting access to clean, structured data is in my opinion one of the most important things we can do.

I would suggest that in the beginning, more early stage checks are better than following up on pro-rata. The valuations are simply better, the portfolio effect makes the chance of hitting a unicorn higher; each $200k at 5% is a $4M valuation; crypto A's are already pushing $30M + which 
is 1/8th the return or so. Once check sizes get larger, there is no choice but to go later; don't think we're there yet if it's a 50 company fund ($10 M at $200 K each). The ROI numbers I've seen for various investment stages are always higher for the earlier stages.

For proving worth, the YC office hours model seems quite good, and in general being available, you're right that has a linear investment of time; one problem I've experienced personally is that there is no end of advice for a founder, the best advice tends to come from founders who have done it (many times) before, to the extent than many things in crypto and being built for this first time this may be somewhat difficult.

Hey everyone, someone in my network recommended I check out this discord. My cofounder and I have been wondering when we'd start seeing Venture DAOs start to self-organize beyond just twitter thread ideas and this is looking like one of the more serious ones so we'd love to introduce ourselves. I'm the CTO of https://paperstreet.vc, on the surface, an email based investor update tool, but under the hood we're an API first startup to investor data communication network.
Imagine Crunchbase, but the company data is real-time and coming straight from the founders and startups. We have an open search API right now that anyone can search through public company information and the ability for portfolios to pull all their information from each company via structured and standardized data streams.
To date we're at ~1500 companies and we’ve been building our platform to serve deal flow pipelines and portfolios of unlimited size. 
Startups have complete control of who can see their updates via data permissioning. In the coming months, we'll be launching Metrics, where you can see a live feed of financial and performance metrics permissionable to be viewed at the founders discretion. 
ps The first iteration of paperstreet was an ICO compliance fundraising platform that was a hit in 2018/2019 but we've since pivotted away to become a data provider to support all types of portfolios (even DAOs). As a result, we've spent almost as much consulting with securities lawyers as we did on our college educations. We've been in and around the crypto community since 2011 as investors, advisors, and friends to many projects over the years. We're excited to finally see venture meet crypto.

We've deliberately not allowed custom schema's per portfolio. But portfolios will be able to pick and choose data from the  standard schema that they are able to request on "application" or "permission handshake". This is the current problem in profiling company data that plagues the investment industry today. Everyone has their own ways of cataloguing companies and this causes immense inconsistencies and time wasted by both investor and companies when sharing information. A singular data schema that can collect all information in a standardized format but can be added to and then consumed/altered in secondary systems is, in our minds, the best first principles solution to the data problem that exists today.

Not sure, I would suggest there be some public data available. Is it binary? And all or none? The stealth comment is meant to encourage talking to users as building in secret is less likely to hit product market fit (there are exceptions but more sciency than w3)

Not binary at all, high level data we recommend to keep public (team, location, website, market verticals, stage, sales motion etc) and sensitive data like revenue, expenses, cac, gmv, churn etc would be individually permissioned. Some companies though want the option of being stealth so the high level data isn’t available in the public api. Most of those companies turn public post launch or post beta though we've noticed.

This is the read side of one of our oldest and most used data input APIs, all posts (company updates) are structured by section so that it can be easily queried (ask, financials, kpis etc). Can even help with NLP. We've been building off the success of this data philosophy in every new addition new the company data schema we make.
It would be great to open source parts of the API and data schema one day so that the community could work together on voting for changes/additions to the schema.

Hi gang. I've seen a lot of thoughts here on AI and modeling and what not. I'm a data scientist in M&A and these are my HOT TAKES:

I have been a data scientist in the M&A space for 3 years. During that time, I have built models for VC funds and PE funds. These models typically had two goals: generate investment leads and predict outcomes for companies using both internal data and alternative data (although usually alternative data). All the data scientists at the VC funds that use the alternative data know each other, and we have a semi agree'd upon approach. It is a small world of people consuming all the raw scraped linkedin data of start ups around the world. 

In VC, we model the outcome of the next round:
Aka if company A's most recent round is a seed round, and has all of these metrics/attributes, what's the probability it receives a series A? Fun fact, the number one predictor was frequently the VC funds involved in the last round. For seed rounds, it was obviously more difficult. 

My thoughts on this as it pertains to Hyperscale were always oriented around gathering as much standardized data up front as possible. Some people have made the extremely fair point that this would create friction in the application process, and I do not have the answer here. All I know is that if our brand is good enough, we can collect data upfront that will give hyperscale a distinct advantage.
Thanks for the insight 👍

If you have the ability to join the data we gather with pitchbook, coresignal, and other alternative data providers, hyperscale will have a 'full picture' on a company that will make reporting/pipeline management easier AND possibly train an AI in the future. I always try to design data ingestion systems so that reporting derives utility just as much as the AI. 

A lot of the work I have done for VC funds was around managing their pipeline and assigning priority. I have a hot take that in a very short amount of time, hyperscale will be getting 5,000 applications per week. You will not regret gathering data when that time arrives 😉
Everything you're saying lines up great with current internal plans. Welcome - we'd love more insight. 😄

i have built these systems for a few funds now and have made lots of mistakes along the way that have been helpful lessons LOL
